   Brad Schimel
   stated on June 26, 2014 in a fund-raising email:
   Says attorney general candidate Jon Richards "went so far to say he would
   only enforce the laws with which he personally agreed."

Schimel's claim

   Asked to provide evidence for Schimel’s claim, campaign manager Johnny
   Koremenos argued that Richards has two standards in deciding whether to
   defend a law, "the Constitution and the ‘wishes of the people.’"

   "This signals he will disregard the law and replace it with his perception
   of the ‘wishes of the people,’" Koremenos said.

Schimel also pointed to the first paragraph of a brief version of an
   Associated Press news story, which stated Richards had pledged to be "the
   people’s attorney general" if elected, and that he said Richards wouldn’t
   defend every state law if he thinks it violates the U.S. Constitution or
   goes against the wishes of the people.

Richards campaign spokesman Sachin Chheda pointed to three such occasions:

     * In March 2014, Richards told the Waukesha Freeman newspaper: "There
       are going to be times when there are laws that I voted against and
       personally might not support but I believe are consistent with the
       state and United States constitution, so, of course, the Department of
       Justice will defend them in that situation."
